title: How Lucky Were The 2022 Minnesota Vikings?
text:
2022 was quite the season for the Minnesota Vikings. Expectations were not too high, with first year head coach Kevin O’Connell coming in to take over for Mike Zimmer. But as the season went on, the team kept winning. Not in convincing fashion however.
They kept making games close, and were known to come back late in games to sneak out a win. The team did that 11 times that year, making fourth quarter comebacks to win. They eventually ended the season with a 13-4 record, and winning the NFC North division title.
With all the comebacks, was this team actually good, or was it luck? There are several things to look at to see this. Margin of Victory (MoV) is something important to look at. How much your team wins by on average throughout the season. How good was the Vikings MoV? It had to be good with 13 wins right? Not really…..


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)

Standings <- read_csv("2022NFLStandings - Sheet1.csv")
  
Margin <- Standings |> 
  select(Tm, MoV) 

SKOL <- Margin |> 
  filter(Tm == "Minnesota Vikings")

Buffalo <- Margin |> 
  filter(Tm == "Buffalo Bills")

Niners <- Margin |> 
  filter(Tm == "San Francisco 49ers")
  
Margin |>   
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=Margin, aes(x=reorder(Tm,MoV), weight=MoV)) +
   geom_bar(data=SKOL, aes(x=reorder(Tm,MoV), weight=MoV), fill="#4F2683") +
   geom_bar(data=Buffalo, aes(x=reorder(Tm,MoV), weight=MoV), fill="#00338D") + 
   geom_bar(data=Niners, aes(x=reorder(Tm,MoV), weight=MoV), fill="#B3995D") +
coord_flip() +
labs(
    x="", 
    y="Margin Of Victory", 
    title="13 Wins Yet A Negative Margin Of Victory", 
    subtitle="The Bills and 49ers were the only other 13 win teams in 2022. Both of those teams were the top two in\n Margin Of Victory.The Vikings were negative in that department", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Josh Quaas"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Middle of the pack….How is that possible? 13 wins and your in the middle of the pack when it comes to MoV. For that statistic, it really does say how lucky they did get. 13-4 record and your average MoV is in the negative…not ideal.
Is this a coincidence? There was two other teams who won 13 games in 2022, and they were both at the top of the league for MoV. So the Vikings must have been bad on one side of the ball then. Simple Rating System (SRS) helps show the overall success of a team’s offense and defense. Was one side of the team holding them back?


Code
SRS <- read_csv("13WinTeams10yrs - Sheet1.csv")

Viks <- SRS |> 
  filter(Team == "22 Vikings") 

SeventeenViks <- SRS |> 
  filter(Team == "17 Vikings")

Broncos <- SRS |> 
  filter(Team == "13 Broncos")

Hawks <- SRS |> 
  filter(Team == "13 Seahawks")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=SRS, aes(x=DSRS, y=OSRS)) +
  geom_point(data=Viks, aes(x=DSRS, y=OSRS, label=Team), color="#FFC62F") +
   geom_point(data=SeventeenViks, aes(x=DSRS, y=OSRS, label=Team), color="#FFC62F") +
   geom_point(data=Broncos, aes(x=DSRS, y=OSRS, label=Team), color="#FB4F14") +
  geom_point(data=Hawks, aes(x=DSRS, y=OSRS, label=Team), color="#69BE28") + 
   geom_text(aes(x=-2.25, y=3.75, label="2022 Vikings"), color="#4F2683") +
  geom_text(aes(x=6.7, y=3, label="2017 Vikings"), color="#4F2683") +
  geom_text(aes(x=-2.25, y=13, label="2013 Broncos"), color="#002244") +
  geom_text(aes(x=8.1, y=4.7, label="2013 Seahawks"), color="#002244") +
labs(
    x="Defensive Simple Rating", 
    y="Offensive Simple Rating",
    title="Minnesota's Defense is Horrible in '22", 
    subtitle="The Vikings have been on both ends of the spectrum for defense. The 2017 team had\n one of the best defenses, while the 2022 team had the worst defense of all 13 win teams from 2013-2022.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Josh Quaas"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









DEFENSE….The phrase defense wins championships sticks out here. The 2022 team had the worst SRS of any team in the last 10 years. The defense is holding the offense back. Who knows where this team could have gone if they had even an average defense.
But what about the fourth quarter comebacks? How did those affect the amount of wins the team had. For sure a good amount. But what if there was no fourth quarter? How good would the team’s point differential be then? In no world would there be three quarters of NFL football anytime soon, but it is interesting where they would fall against the rest of the NFC if there was.


Code
threequarters <- read_csv("Teamsdifferential3quarters - Sheet1.csv")

Teams <- c("Eagles", "Cowboys", "Giants", "Commanders", "Vikings", "Packers", "Lions", "Bears", "49ers", "Seahawks", "Cardinals", "Rams", "Buccaneers", "Saints", "Falcons", "Panthers")

threequarters |> 
  arrange(desc(PointDifferential)) |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    PointDifferential = "Point Differential",
    Wins = "W"
    ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Vikings Forget How To Play First Three Quarters",
    subtitle = "Minnesota is closer to last place in point differential throughout the first three quarters than the spot ahead of them. Kirk Cousins and the offense had to save them week in and week out."
  ) |> 
   tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Josh Quaas  |  **Source:** https://www.sportsreference.com")
  ) |> 
   tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |> 
   tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=14)
     )
   ) |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |> 
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#4F2683"),
      cell_text(color = "#FFC62F")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Vikings")
  )

Minnesota is closer to last place in point differential throughout the first three quarters than the spot ahead of them. Kirk Cousins and the offense had to save them week in and week out.

Yikes. 14/16 in just your own conference. What does this all mean? It means that this team did need to rely on some luck to win football games. If there was no fourth quarter this team would have been at the bottom of the NFC, preparing for the NFL Draft. Instead they made the playoffs, getting a home playoff game for the first time since 2017 when they had the Minneapolis Miracle against the Saints.
What it all boils down to is yes, this team did get very lucky and fortunate with all the comebacks late in games. They however showed their true colors in the NFC Wild Card game, when they lost to Daniel Jones and the New York Giants. You can’t rely on luck all the time to win football games.

title: Which Power Five Conference Has Peformed The Best Over The Last Five Full Seasons
text:
The Power Five is no more this upcoming college football season, with the Pac-12 Conference dissolving with all of it’s teams leaving to different conferences. So lets look back on the last five full seasons, which excludes the 2020 season, to see where all five of these conferences ranked throughout those years and who is number one.
When fans talk about the best Power Five conference, they always debate who is the best conference. Is it the SEC? Big Ten? or maybe there is an argument for the other three as well.
Metrics like Simple Rating System (SRS) were used. SRS is a metric that measures the average point differential and strength of schedule. Who has been on top over the last five full seasons SRS wise?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

srs <- read_csv("PowerfiveSRS - Sheet1.csv")

SEC <- srs |> 
  filter(Conf == "SEC")

BIG <- srs |> 
  filter(Conf == "Big Ten")

Bigtwelve <- srs |> 
  filter(Conf == "Big 12")

PAC <- srs |> 
  filter(Conf == "Pac-12")

ACC <- srs |> 
  filter(Conf == "ACC")

 ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=SEC, aes(x=Year, y=SRS, group=Conf), color="gold") + geom_line(data=BIG, aes(x=Year, y=SRS, group=Conf), color="cyan") + geom_line(data=Bigtwelve, aes(x=Year, y=SRS, group=Conf), color="red") + geom_line(data=PAC, aes(x=Year, y=SRS, group=Conf), color="darkblue") + geom_line(data=ACC, aes(x=Year, y=SRS, group=Conf), color="darkgrey")+ 
  geom_text(aes(x=2018, y=6.82, label="Big 12"), color="red") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2018, y=10.9, label="SEC"), color="gold") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2018, y=6, label="Big Ten"), color="cyan") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2018, y=4.79, label="ACC"), color="darkgrey") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2018, y=3.33, label="Pac-12"), color="darkblue") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2023.1, y=5.72, label="5.92"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2023.1, y=7.98, label="7.68"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2023.1, y=6.43, label="6.43"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2023.1, y=4.25, label="4.35"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2023.1, y=7, label="6.86"), color="black") +
  labs(
    x="Season", 
    y="Simple Rating System", 
    title="The SEC Leads In Simple Rating System", 
    subtitle="The SEC has controlled the top spot for most of the last five years. Everybody but\nthe ACC has been in second for atleast one year.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Josh Quaas"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The SEC has been the top conference in terms of SRS four of the last five full seasons. So does that mean that they are the top conference? Not quite. There are other metrics to use to measure this as well.
SRS measures regular season statistics, but that is not the only part of the college football season. Bowl games and the college football playoff exist. How do we measure who has been the best in terms of postseason games in college football? We can look at bowl game wins and winning percentage. Winning percentage is key to look at since conferences can have different amount of teams in them. Who has performed the best in late December and early January?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

bowls <- read_csv("CFBPostseason - Sheet1.csv")

Conferences <- c("Big Ten", "SEC", "Pac-12", "Big 12", "ACC")

bowls |> 
  arrange(desc(Wins)) |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TotalGames = "Total Games",
    WinPercentage = "Win %",
    CFBPlayoffAppearences = "CFB Playoff Appearences",
    Wins = "W",
    Losses = "L"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Who Is The Best Conference In Postseason Games",
    subtitle = "The SEC once again is on top, including three championships. The SEC and Big Ten are the only two conferences with over .500 winning percentages in bowl games the past five full seasons."
  ) |> 
   tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Josh Quaas  |  **Source:** (https://www.sportsreference.com")
  ) |> 
   tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |> 
   tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=14)
     )
   ) |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |> 
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "darkblue"),
      cell_text(color = "gold")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Conference == "SEC")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "black"),
      cell_text(color = "cyan")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Conference == "Big Ten")
  )

The SEC once again is on top, including three championships. The SEC and Big Ten are the only two conferences with over .500 winning percentages in bowl games the past five full seasons.

Well, look who is on top once again. Not by much, but the SEC has the most bowl wins, best winning percentage, and three championships in the past five full seasons. The biggest difference was the winning percentage between the SEC and Big Ten vs the other three.
We’ve pretty much established who is at the top of the mountain for the Power Five, but does the name “Power Five” really resonate. Are all five of these conferences the top five in the country? We can measure that by combining wins and losses over the last five full seasons and see the total winning percentage.


Code
library(tidyverse)

wl <- read_csv("Conftotalwinpercentage - Sheet1.csv")
BIG <- wl |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Big Ten"
  )  
  SEC <- wl |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "SEC"
  )  
  ACC <- wl |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "ACC"
  )  
  PAC <- wl |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Pac-12"
  ) 
  BTwelve <- wl |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Big 12"
  ) 
wl |> 
  ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=wl, aes(x=reorder(Conference, WinPercentage), weight=WinPercentage)) +
  geom_bar(data=BIG, aes(x=reorder(Conference, WinPercentage), weight=WinPercentage), fill="black") +
   geom_bar(data=SEC, aes(x=reorder(Conference, WinPercentage), weight=WinPercentage), fill="darkblue") +
   geom_bar(data=ACC, aes(x=reorder(Conference, WinPercentage), weight=WinPercentage), fill="black") +
   geom_bar(data=PAC, aes(x=reorder(Conference, WinPercentage), weight=WinPercentage), fill="black") +
   geom_bar(data=BTwelve, aes(x=reorder(Conference, WinPercentage), weight=WinPercentage), fill="black") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="Conference", 
    y="Win Percentage Over The Last Five Full Seasons", 
    title="The Power Five Stands Tall In Winning %", 
    subtitle="The SEC by these statistics have won the best percentage of their games over the\nlast five full seasons. All Power Five Conferences are in the top five.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Josh Quaas"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    ) 









Well, look at that. They are called the Power Five for a reason. However, conferences like the Sun Belt, American, and Mountain West aren’t as far behind for that fifth spot as a lot of people would think.
We definitely established that the SEC by all these metrics, is the No. 1 Conference in the Power Five. The Big Ten and Big 12 were neck and neck for second, while the ACC and Pac-12 are the two weakest conferences of the Power Five.
